comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Can anyone shed any light on the writing on the roof of the Weigh House? I think I can make out 'Streamstown' and 'Corless' for starters ...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Streamstown is in Co. Westmeath and was a station/junction on the Midland & Great Western Railway (as on the moustachioed chap's cap). I thought the word after Corless is Proprietor or Proprietors. Confirmed by an online search, where I found a PhD thesis on the "Emergence, Development and Influence of French Haute Cuisine on Public Dining in Dublin Restaurants 1900-2000: An Oral History" by Máirtín Mac Con Iomaire. Presumably the women here had oysters in their baskets/creels/panniers, because apparently this was the site of the oyster market in Clifden, and this "shed" belonged to a Joseph Corless who had 700 acres of oyster beds in Clifden Bay. Info. is on p. 103/104 and there's a photo of the shed on p. 104 where all of the roof can be seen...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Here's his advert from Freeman's Journal in August 1878 By 1888 Joseph had died and the business had been taken over by his brother Thomas.

comment._content: Where are the chains for lifting the load and the pan for holding the measuring weights? Yes, I do resemble the old man. It's been a long winter and the whiskers will not be trimmed until the spring.

comment._content: You asked about the animal and it has to be a donkey as its facing towards you!  The other way around would be an ass:-O  It is neither a mule or a gennet but of the family that carried the Lord into Jerusalem on that fateful day.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: Looks like a hydrant made by Glenfields and Kennedy of Kilmarnock Scotland. They were the main makers and suppliers of street hydrants in Ireland. www.glenfield.co.uk/history.html
